Legal_Issue: Application of res judicata and sufficiency of evidence in refugee claims
Procedural_Context: Second refugee claim following dismissal of first unchallenged claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' fear of persecution found not credible due to lack of evidence
Evidence_Type: Lack of documentary or testimonial evidence showing targeted persecution
Legal_Provision: Section 101(1)(a) IRPA – definition of Convention refugee
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on nationality and religion in Israel
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Res judicata and insufficient new evidence
Regulation_Cited: IRPR Section 108 – duplicate claims and res judicata
Legal_Standard: Res judicata and burden of proof in refugee claims
Application_Factor: Failure to challenge prior decision; lack of new compelling evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed as inadmissible under res judicata
Decision_Review_Issue: Whether the tribunal correctly applied res judicata and assessed evidence
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: Res judicata principle; Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention
Cause_of_Refusal: Prior unchallenged dismissal and lack of evidence of persecution
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence to establish targeted persecution or lack of state protection
Procedural_Fairness: No breach found in procedural fairness by the tribunal
Credibility_Issues: Applicants' claims lacked credibility due to inconsistencies and absence of supporting evidence
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Applicants did not appeal first decision; second claim treated as duplicate
Jurisdictional_Focus: Canada – Federal immigration and refugee law
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, regulations, and international refugee principles
Procedural_Issue: Admissibility of a subsequent claim under res judicata
Omission_Type: Failure to provide evidence of changed country conditions or personal circumstances
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Duplicate claim; lack of credible basis for fear of persecution
